Harnessing the Daily Dev Chrome plugin is akin to clutching a luxurious, high-gloss magazine that never runs out of pages. It transforms the arduous task of staying abreast with the ever-evolving tech sphere into a delightful escapade. My general IT acumen has skyrocketed, traversing beyond my immediate purview into realms I'm ostensibly not required to master—yet here I am, navigating the tempestuous seas of AI, low-code revolutions, and the weekly unfurling of new frameworks with the ease o... I've been a user of daily.dev for some time, and I like the _service_ great, if rating the service, 5 stars.  My problem is with the extension.

I understand the recent change to require permissions to update javascript on all websites so that you can put your little sidebar on sites after following a link from a news article, keeps the conversation thread flowing, that _would_ be fine... except that it doesn't work and it breaks other sites.

It's not like the content is any different.

It's start to force users to create account/login to easier to track them.

The quality of the content that is curated to appear on your new tab is really impressive.  If you register and sign in, you are able to select topics that interest you.  Visually the new tab page looks very enticing and it requires some discipline to only bookmark the cards that look really interesting and then read them when you're taking a planned break.  Never before in my career have I been this informed about the latest industry trends.

I have only one minor "problem" with this extension.. Quite often I open a new tab to load a very specific page that I need to view, suddenly spot a whole bunch of really interesting looking articles, and then I forget what I opened that new tab for in the first place.

If I had to offer only one tip for anybody using this extension: open your new tab, TYPE THE ADDRESS YOU NEED, and then go wild and middle-click (or ctrl-click) on all the articles you want. (:
